quizTitle: Secondary 1 Science: Laboratory Safety & Hazard Symbols
instructions: Answer all questions about lab safety rules, GHS hazard symbols, and Bunsen burner use. Choose the safest/correct answer.

questions.question: What should you always do before starting any experiment?
options: Tie long hair back and wear safety goggles
Ask a friend to watch your bag
Skip reading the procedure to save time
questions.explanation: Safety first! Goggles protect eyes. Tied hair prevents fire/contact hazards. Always read instructions first.

questions.question: If you spill a chemical on your skin, you should:
options: Wipe it off with your sleeve
Rinse immediately under running water for 15+ minutes
Wait to see if it stings
questions.explanation: Flush spills immediately with water. Report to teacher right away ‚Äì even if it seems minor!

questions.question: A symbol showing a skull and crossbones (‚ò†Ô∏è) means the chemical is:
questions.explanation: ‚ò†Ô∏è Skull = ACUTE TOXICITY. Even small amounts can be deadly. Never taste chemicals. Use in fume hood with gloves/goggles.

questions.question: A symbol with a flame (üî•) means the substance is:
questions.explanation: üî• Flame = FLAMMABLE. Keep away from flames, sparks, or heat sources (e.g., ethanol, acetone, petrol).

questions.question: A symbol showing liquid dripping onto a hand and surface (‚ö†Ô∏è with corrosion) means the chemical is:
questions.explanation: ‚ö†Ô∏è Corrosive chemicals (e.g., sulfuric acid, sodium hydroxide) cause severe burns. ALWAYS wear gloves and goggles!

questions.question: A symbol showing a dead fish and a dead tree (üå≤üêü) means the chemical is:
questions.explanation: üå≤üêü Environmental hazard = harms rivers, fish, plants. NEVER pour chemicals down the sink. Dispose as directed by teacher.

questions.question: A symbol with an exclamation mark (‚ùó) often means the chemical can:
questions.explanation: ‚ùó Exclamation mark = IRRITANT or mild hazard. May cause itchy skin, red eyes, or headache. Still requires care‚Äîwear gloves/goggles.

questions.question: An 'aspiration hazard' means a liquid could:
options: Enter lungs if vomited/swallowed, causing severe damage
questions.explanation: Aspiration hazard = if swallowed/vomited, liquid enters lungs (not stomach), causing chemical pneumonia. Examples: some oils, solvents. NEVER induce vomiting‚Äîseek help immediately.

questions.question: Which part of the Bunsen burner controls air flow?
questions.explanation: Rotating the collar opens/closes air holes. More air = hotter blue flame. Less air = cooler yellow flame.

questions.question: Before lighting a Bunsen burner, you should:
options: Close air holes, then light, then adjust
Light it first, then connect tubing
questions.explanation: SAFETY STEP: Close air holes ‚Üí light match ‚Üí turn on gas ‚Üí light burner ‚Üí adjust air holes. Prevents 'strike-back' (flame shooting back into barrel)!

questions.question: If your Bunsen burner flame goes out accidentally, you should:
options: Turn off gas tap, wait 30 seconds, then relight
Blow on the barrel to clear gas
questions.explanation: Gas may accumulate! Turn off gas ‚Üí wait for gas to disperse ‚Üí relight safely. Prevents fire/explosion risk.

questions.question: Which two hazard symbols BOTH require you to wear safety goggles?
options: All hazard symbols require eye protection
questions.explanation: ‚úÖ ALWAYS wear goggles in lab‚Äîregardless of hazard type. Splashes, fumes, or flying particles can harm eyes with ANY chemical.

questions.question: The base of the Bunsen burner is important because it:
questions.explanation: Heavy metal base keeps burner stable. Never place near edge of bench‚Äîknocking it over causes fire!

questions.question: Long hair or loose clothing near a Bunsen burner is dangerous because:
questions.explanation: üî• FIRE HAZARD! Tie back long hair, secure loose sleeves/jewellery. Safety goggles must be worn at all times near flames.

questions.question: After finishing an experiment with chemicals, you should:
options: Leave equipment for the next class
Dispose of waste in labelled containers as instructed
Take interesting chemicals home to show family
questions.explanation: ‚úÖ NEVER pour chemicals down sink (environmental hazard!). ‚úÖ NEVER take chemicals home. ‚úÖ ALWAYS follow teacher's disposal instructions.
